title: Sudden Mixed Hearing Loss Following Barotrauma and URI
chief_complaint: I was on a flight last week and felt pain and pressure in my left ear. I heard a loud pop, and ever since then, my hearing has been down and I hear a roaring sound.

problem_summary.onset: Sudden onset during an airplane flight one week prior.
problem_summary.course: Constant decreased hearing and tinnitus since the incident.
problem_summary.laterality: Left ear (acute symptoms); Right ear (chronic history with PE tube).
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Otalgia (ear pain), aural fullness/pressure, tinnitus (ringing/roaring), and occasional 'whoozy' feeling.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Difficulty hearing in the left ear.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Resolution of hearing loss and pressure.

history.present_illness: Patient reports sudden hearing decrease in the left ear (LE) following a flight last week. Experienced otalgia and pressure, heard a loud 'pop', followed by hearing loss and tinnitus. Had an upper respiratory infection (URI) prior to the flight.
history.otologic_history: Right ear (RE) has had a pressure equalization (PE) tube for 1-2 months.
history.prior_management: PE tube placement in Right Ear.
history.patient_goals: Diagnosis and treatment of sudden left ear hearing loss.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right Ear: Normal thresholds 250-2000 Hz, sloping to moderate high-frequency loss. Left Ear: Slight-to-moderate mixed loss in lows (250-1000 Hz), rising to mild SNHL at 2000 Hz, sloping to moderate/severe mixed loss in highs. Significant air-bone gaps present in LE.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Speech Reception Thresholds (SRT) agree with pure-tone averages. Word Recognition Scores (WRS) are excellent bilaterally.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Right Ear: Large ear canal volume with excessive negative pressure (Type C/Patent Tube mix). Left Ear: Flat tympanogram (Type B) consistent with fluid.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a mixed hearing loss in the left ear, characterized by air-bone gaps in the low and high frequencies and a flat tympanogram, consistent with middle ear pathology. The right ear demonstrates high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss with a large ear canal volume consistent with a patent pressure equalization tube, though negative pressure was noted.
counseling_points: The test results indicate fluid behind your left eardrum, likely caused by the combination of your recent cold and the pressure changes during your flight ('airplane ear').
This fluid is preventing sound from traveling through your ear efficiently, which causes the hearing loss and the 'underwater' sensation.
The doctor has prescribed an antibiotic (Augmentin) to treat the infection.
We recommend 'autoinsufflation' exercises—gently popping your ears—to help open the Eustachian tube and drain the fluid.
If the fluid does not clear with medication and exercises, a small tube (PE tube) might need to be placed in your left ear, similar to the one you have in your right ear.
notes_for_actor: Portray a patient who is uncomfortable due to the pressure and 'clogged' feeling in the left ear.
Mention feeling a bit 'whoozy' or off-balance occasionally.
Emphasize the specific event of the 'loud pop' on the airplane as the start of the severe symptoms.
